{{for|the Canadian author|Sean Costello (author)}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Sean Costello | image = Sean_Costello_by_Donald_Schellhaas.JPG | caption = Sean Costello performing at [[Tipitina's]], [[New Orleans]] on March 11, 2005 (photo: Donald Schellhaas) | image_size = 250 | Portrait = Yes | background = solo_singer | birth_name = | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date |1979|4|16|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]], [[United States]] | death_date = {{dda|2008|4|15|1979|4|16|mf=y}} | death_place = [[Atlanta, Georgia|Atlanta]], United States | instrument = [[Guitar]], [[vocals]] | genre = [[Blues]], [[Soul music|soul]] | years_active = 1995–2008 }} '''Sean Costello''' (April 16, 1979 – April 15, 2008) was an [[United States|American]] [[blues]] [[musician]], renowned for his fiery guitar playing and soulful singing.{{cite web|url=http://deltagrooveproductions.com/music/reviews/seancostello/wecangettogether/elmore_sean.pdf |title=Elmore Magazine, April–May 2008, p. 36 |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}{{cite web|url=http://deltagrooveproductions.com/music/reviews/seancostello/wecangettogether/bigcityblues.pdf |title=Big City Blues Magazine, February–March 2008, p. 46 |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}{{cite web|author=iNet Technologies, www.inetzone.com |url=http://www.vintageguitar.com/newswire/detail.asp?newsID=258 |title=Vintage Guitar magazine, February 2008 |publisher=Vintageguitar.com |date=2008-02-21 |accessdate=2011-02-06}} He released five critically acclaimed albums before his career was cut short by his sudden death at the age of 28. [[Tinsley Ellis]] called him ‘the most gifted young blues guitarist on the scene... he was a triple threat on guitar, vocals and as a songwriter’.{{cite web|url=http://www.jambands.com/News.phtml?newsfile=redesign_news363.html |title=Obituary by Rob Turner, April 16, 2008 |publisher=Jambands |date=2008-04-14 |accessdate=2011-02-06}} ==Career== Costello mastered traditional blues guitar at an early age and began his career while still in high school. His records became increasingly eclectic as his career progressed.{{cite web|url=http://deltagrooveproductions.com/music/reviews/seancostello/articles/bluesrevue.html |title=Interview in Blues Revue, April 2008 |publisher=Deltagrooveproductions.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}{{cite web|url=http://deltagrooveproductions.com/music/reviews/seancostello/articles/savannah.html |title=Interview in Connect Savannah, April 2008 |publisher=Deltagrooveproductions.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}} ===Early years=== Born in [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]], [[United States]], Costello moved to [[Atlanta, Georgia]] at the age of nine. Obsessive about the guitar from a young age, he got hooked on the blues after buying [[Howlin’ Wolf]]'s [[Howlin' Wolf (album)|'Rockin' Chair Album']].{{cite web|author=Sean Costello : Guitar Lifestyle says: |url=http://a1artistspotlight.com/2008/04/17/031-sean-costello-%E2%80%93-up-and-coming-blues-legend-passes-away/# |title=A1 Artist Spotlight interview, April 14, 2008 |publisher=A1artistspotlight.com |date=2008-04-17 |accessdate=2011-02-06}} At 14 the young prodigy created a stir in a [[Memphis, Tennessee|Memphis]] guitar shop, where an employee tipped his father off about a talent contest sponsored by the Beale Street Blues Society, which Costello duly entered and won. He formed his first band shortly after.{{cite web|url=http://deltagrooveproductions.com/music/reviews/seancostello/inmemoriam/creativeloafing.html |title=Creative Loafing, June 4, 2008 |publisher=Deltagrooveproductions.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}} At sixteen, Costello recorded his first album, ''Call The Cops'' (1996), already ‘displaying a flawless command of 1950s blues guitar’, in the words of music historian Tony Russell.{{cite news|author=Tony Russell |url=http://music.guardian.co.uk/obituaries/story/0,,2279704,00.html |title=Obituary: Sean Costello | Music | The Guardian |publisher=Music.guardian.co.uk |date= 2008-05-14|accessdate=2011-02-06 |location=London}} His lead guitar work on [[Susan Tedeschi]]'s [[RIAA certification|gold-selling]] album, ''Just Won't Burn,'' (1998), subsequently brought him national exposure. Costello's band later toured as Tedeschi's backing group. "His playing is shockingly deep for a 20-year old", wrote the [[Allmusic]] guide of Costello's second album, ''Cuttin’ In'' (2000),[{{Allmusic|class=album|id=r461695|pure_url=yes}} Allmusic review of ''Cuttin' In''] which was nominated for a [[Blues Music Award|W. C. Handy Award]] for Best New Artist Debut.[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p199857/biography|pure_url=yes}} Allmusic biography] The follow-up, ''Moanin’ For Molasses'', was equally well received; the Allmusic guide drew attention to Costello's "soulful voice" and his "ability to mesh blues, [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]] and soul".[{{Allmusic|class=album|id=r533193|pure_url=yes}} Allmusic review of ''Moanin' For Molasses''] "Passionate... distinctive and often compelling... Costello's vocals are most astonishing," reported Blues Revue Magazine.[http://media.www.fsunews.com/media/storage/paper920/news/2003/06/09/ArtsAndEntertainment/friday.The.13th.Terrorized.By.Blues-2364872.shtml Blues Revue Magazine's review of ''Moanin' For Molasses'']{{dead link|date=February 2011}} ===In concert=== Costello honed his skills through almost constant performing, playing over 300 gigs a year and touring widely in the [[USA]] and [[Europe]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bluessource.com/readarticles.php?id=40 |title=Blues Source live preview |publisher=Bluessource.com |date=2008-08-08 |accessdate=2011-02-06}} His reputation as a brilliant live performer enabled him to play alongside blues luminaries such as [[B. B. King]] and [[Buddy Guy]] ([[Ma Rainey]] House benefit concert, [[Columbus, Georgia]], June 1997), [[James Cotton]] (Cotton's 64th birthday concert in Memphis) and [[Hubert Sumlin]] ([[South by Southwest]], [[Austin, Texas]], March 2005). When not touring, Costello made a living playing small venues in his home town of Atlanta, Georgia, such as the [http://www.northsidetavern.com/ Northside Tavern]. Richard Rosenblatt, former President of Tone-Cool Records, recalls Costello's performances:
As a guitarist he was astounding, but for Sean it was never about showing off monstrous chops or stroking his own ego. His playing always fit the song; he would work the tone and phrasing, sometimes with an economy of notes that let the empty spaces hang achingly for what seemed like hours. When he did take off on the occasional blazing run, he was the ultimate tightrope walker, flirting fearlessly with danger before bringing it all back home with the unlikeliest of phrases that was still, somehow, perfect.{{cite web|url=http://deltagrooveproductions.com/music/reviews/seancostello/inmemoriam/elmore.pdf |title=Recollections from Richard Rosenblatt, Elmore, June 2008 |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}
===Later career=== Through Amy Helm of [[Ollabelle]], Costello met her father, [[Americana (music)|Americana]] musician [[Levon Helm]], formerly of [[The Band]],{{cite web|last=Radford |first=Chad |url=http://blogs.creativeloafing.com/cribnotes/2008/06/11/levon-helm-remembers-sean-costello/ |title=Levon Helm on Sean Costello |publisher=Blogs.creativeloafing.com |date=2008-06-11 |accessdate=2011-02-06}} whose eclecticism encouraged Costello to further develop his interests outside the blues: "he really blew it wide open for me. He’d play a [[Chuck Berry]] tune, then a blues, then a [[Country music|country]] tune or a [[Rock music|rock]] number or whatever, and he didn’t even think twice about it." Levon Helm and the members of Ollabelle were among the contributors to Costello’s fourth, self-titled album, recorded in [[New York]] with input from local musicians. With an eclectic set list, and arrangements reminiscent more of [[Memphis soul]] than [[Chicago blues]], ''Sean Costello'' (2005) marked a departure from his earlier work.{{cite web|url=http://www.sierrabluessociety.org/Reviews7.htm#Costello |title=Sierra Blues Society review of ''Sean Costello'' |publisher=Sierrabluessociety.org |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}} Costello’s guitar took a backseat to his voice, which by now "had acquired a ragged edge of considerable power" (Tony Russell). In 2007 Costello's playing on [[Nappy Brown]]'s comeback album, ''Long Time Coming'', was singled out for praise by the critics.[{{Allmusic|class=album|id=r1205943/review|pure_url=yes}} Allmusic review of ''Long Time Coming'']{{cite web|url=http://www.bobcorritore.com/ltc-rev.html |title=Blues Bytes review of ''Long Time Coming'', December 2007 |publisher=Bobcorritore.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bobcorritore.com/ltc-rev.html |title=Blueswax review of ''Long Time Coming'', October 25, 2007 |publisher=Bobcorritore.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bobcorritore.com/ltc-rev.html |title=Music City Blues review of ''Long Time Coming October 5, 2007 |publisher=Bobcorritore.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}} The following year Costello released what was to be his last album, ''We Can Get Together'', acclaimed by many as his best work.[{{Allmusic|class=album|id=r1311835|pure_url=yes}} Allmusic review of ''We Can Get Together'']{{cite web|url=http://deltagrooveproductions.com/music/reviews/seancostello/wecangettogether/bluesinthenorthwest.html |title=Blues In The Northwest review of ''We Can Get Together'', March 2008 |publisher=Deltagrooveproductions.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}{{cite web|url=http://deltagrooveproductions.com/music/reviews/seancostello/wecangettogether/examiner.html |title=The Examiner's review of ''We Can Get Together'', February 2008 |publisher=Deltagrooveproductions.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}{{cite web|url=http://deltagrooveproductions.com/music/reviews/seancostello/wecangettogether/wny.html |title=WNY's review of ''We Can Get Together'', June 2008 |publisher=Deltagrooveproductions.com |date=2008-04-15 |accessdate=2011-02-06}} His guitar playing on this record was described variously as "incendiary", "searing", and "blistering red hot". It earned Costello two [[Blues Music Awards|Blues Music Award]] nominations for Best Contemporary Album and Best Contemporary Male Artist.{{cite web|url=http://www.blues.org/bluesmusicawards/nominees.php4 |title=Blues Music Award nominees, 2009 |publisher=Blues.org |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}} Hal Horowitz of the Allmusic guide summed up ''We Can Get Together'' with the following:
The material is so strong and the ensemble playing of his band so effortless that he doesn't need to distract attention from the songs with the extended soloing he is capable of. Most importantly, he establishes a greasy groove that weaves through each cut, connecting them even when the styles differ. While Costello is clearly inspired by the blues greats, many of whom he has covered on previous collections, he slants more to '70s [[Southern soul]], rock, and R&B here, dousing these genres with a bucket load of swamp water and spearheaded by his whiskey-laced vocals. There's a thick, gooey atmospheric vibe that hangs over the album, gels its contents, and shows Costello to be a terrific singer and songwriter and guitar talent just hitting his peak.
===Death=== Sean Costello was found dead in his [[Atlanta, Georgia|Atlanta]] hotel room on April 15, 2008, one day before his 29th birthday.{{cite web|last=Eldredge |first=Richard L. |url=http://www.accessatlanta.com/music/content/music/stories/2008/04/16/costello_0416.html |title=Atlanta blues guitarist Sean Costello found dead |publisher=Accessatlanta.com |date=2008-04-16 |accessdate=2011-02-06}}{{cite web|author=Posted: 1:38 pm EDT April 16, 2008 |url=http://www.wsbtv.com/news/15900187/detail.html |title=Atlanta Bluesman Sean Costello Found Dead |publisher=Wsbtv.com |date=2008-04-16 |accessdate=2011-02-06}} A medical report later determined that he died of an accidental drug overdose.{{cite web|last=Radford |first=Chad |url=http://blogs.creativeloafing.com/cribnotes/2008/06/03/sean-costellos-autopsy-cites-accidental-drug-overdose/ |title=Sean Costello's autopsy cites accidental drug overdose |publisher=Blogs.creativeloafing.com |date=2008-06-03 |accessdate=2011-02-06}} Posthumously, Costello's family revealed that he had suffered from [[bipolar disorder]], and set up the [http://www.seancostellofund.org/ Sean Costello Memorial Fund for Bipolar Research] in his honor. ==Ancestry== Costello was a probable descendant of [[Jocelyn de Angulo]] (fl. 1172), ancestor to the
